Entries.default: A soul stands before you, shimmering and indistinct, her sharp elven features fading to nothing at the edges and extremities.

"You trespass."

The soul's voice seems to come from everywhere at once - from her, from the air around you, and from within your own mind. Its chill runs down the sides of your neck, a numbness descending from your ears to your shoulders.
The figure takes a step closer, and the air grows colder, drier. Frost spreads from her feet.
"I'll help if I can."
"You tried to kill that monster? Do you know what it is?"
"Before it came here, it was a dragon. What it has become since, exactly, I cannot say."
"It fell upon our temple wielding powerful wizardry. I believed that it desired the temple itself, or our accumulated lore."
"I was mistaken."
"I need to find that dragon."
"Then you must seek it below. Know that the White Void will consume you, however."
"A few souls here cling tenaciously to coherence, some for as long as centuries. Seek them if you would know the secrets of their longevity."
"I imagine, though, that the Beast of Winter would prefer you hasten their dissolution."
Rynhaedr bows her head to you.
"You retain yourself. Your life. Your awareness. Your soul. How?"
[Show her the Eye of Rymrgand.] "Rymrgand gave me this."
"To succeed where I have failed."
"You must be pretty familiar with this place."
"It is a place between places. A well descending into the White Void, where all things are as nothing."
"How do I close the Vytmádh?"
"I've come to think of it as the Shattered Passage."
"If I leave it be, ice will cover the whole Deadfire."

"Everything ends eventually."

Sighing, she shakes her head.
"Do as you will, so long as you slay the wyrm."
"I should probably leave this place. The Deadfire needs me whole in body and soul."
"Go then. This will resolve itself in rime and ruin."
"Was there something else you wished to ask?"
"Why do you address me in Aedyran?"
"Can you tell me more about these echo realms?"
[Leave] "Farewell."
"I can tell you of but three. There are others, but they exist beyond my ken."
"There's an entire sunken kingdom down here?"
"Are there other realms?"
"What did you mean by 'chained in questions?'"
"You know nothing else of the youngest realm?"
"I want to talk about something else."
"Each reflects the souls within, spirits adrift upon the calamity that claimed them. Some souls cling more tightly than others."
"A drowned kingdom of salt and coral. A copper realm chained in questions. These were here when I arrived."
"The third realm is young yet, and as hot as a festival flame."
"I know no other words for it. Agonized screams echo through its halls, and great machines churn above masked querents."
"It is an ancient nightmare sustained by the bitterness and spite of the kith within."
"I speak the tongue of my people. If you perceive it as your own, it is because of this place."
You recognize her form as that of the armored corpse standing frozen in the temple beyond the portal.
"I didn't see a lock on the door."
"Alright, you get on in there now." Xoti wiggles her lantern at the being.
Vatnir gapes at the phantasm and retreats a step towards the portal.
"I have an invitation."
"It's something of a habit of mine."
"Trespass where exactly?"
"Xoti, you want to put that lantern of yours to use?"
The ghost's ephemeral eyes follow the lantern to either side, but she seems otherwise unaffected. Her attention returns to you.
"Yes. You and all others. Yet you arrive before the appointed hour." Her brow furrows.
"Or perhaps after."
She says nothing in response, instead holding your gaze in her own.
"Not much of a talker, eh?"
"Apologies. Sometimes my mouth gets away from me."
"Just tell me what you want."
"Within the dread dominion of Rymrgand. The realm of the dead."
"What do you mean?"
"You seem a little dazed."
"I'm a Watcher."
"I don't know."

"Do I?"

Her head tilts slightly as she searches your features.
"Dissolution attends everything that comes to this place. Such is the nature of the realm."
"I prove no exception. I spent myself in calling out to Rymrgand. What remains stands sentinel here. Against the wyrm."
"Interesting. And advantageous, I suspect. But relevant?"
Her eyebrows knit over a ghost of a frown. She shrugs.
The spirit's eyes widen as she reaches towards the orb. She stops short, fingers twitching, before letting her hand drop to her side. Her attention falls to the frozen ground.
"Who are you anyway?"
"Your presence suggests that Rymrgand has chosen a new guardian to put the wyrm to the blade."
"I was Rynhaedr of the gandhur. Now I am merely the shade you see before you."
"I saw your body outside the portal."
She nods slowly.
"We could protect neither the temple nor the Vytmádh. I called upon the Beast of Winter, and his rime fell upon us, slaying us where we stood."
"When was that, exactly?"
"Even that proved insufficient. The last thing I saw as frost took my sight was the wyrm clawing past us and into the Maw."
"Long ago. I know not how you reckon such things."
"Had Aedyr lost control over the Dyrwood yet?"
"Armor like yours hasn't been made for centuries."
"What year was it?"
"Fair enough."
"The Dyrwood?" She frowns at the word.

"Centuries? Yes, it may have been centuries ago."

She peers uncertainly across the strange landscape around you.
"I know not the name. Aedyr was the alliance of Meadowfolk and Sceltrfolc, correct? It was young yet."
"I'd seen almost one hundred winters. A good life. A long life."
She says nothing - only stares.
"If this spirit's memory is true, then she's been bound here for well over two centuries."
Edér starts counting on his fingers. Losing track, he curses under his breath and starts again several times.
"Aedyr formed roughly four centuries ago, but it only established its Dyrwood colony within the last two." She taps her upper lip with a single extended finger.
"She must have been here for at least two centuries if she does not even know of the Dyrwood."
"Why? It is sacred to Rymrgand." A confused frown mars her face.
"That cleared everything right up."
"A place between places? Does that have to do with these paths?"
"How is it that the White Void reduces everything to nothing?"
"Let me ask you about something else."
She smiles, albeit only faintly. It seems your sarcasm wasn't entirely lost on her.
"They lead to places that are no more and times that have passed. This place digests them."
"Nothing is exactly as it was, despite inevitable similarities. "
"We are never our mothers. Even if they'd have us be."
"So those portals lead to dead places?"

"To echoes of lost pasts. Is that clearer?" 

An uncertain frown dominates her white features.
"This is the realm of Rymrgand. The endless winter. The closing verse of the final vesper."
"It is the end."

"It is no different for us. Souls brought here fragment. Crumble into dust. His children collect the detritus and deliver it unto the void." She gestures to the still, uneven form that the dragon left in its wake.
"Sounds perfectly safe."
"I want to talk about something else."
"Greetings again, walker between worlds."
"Does that mean it's dangerous to be here?"
"Not at all. It means only that your soul will be dissolved and disposed of."
"What was the dragon after?"
"Rymrgand gifted our people with the Vytmádh that we might yield to him those objects or individuals that persisted beyond their... value to the clans."

"In its desire to dominate the Deadfire, the wyrm sought to retrieve one or more of the sacrificed relics."

Her scowl twists into a smirk.
"Even if it claimed the relics, the fool cannot return, its body long since destroyed."
"Still, its soul persists against the power of this place, and I would see it ended."
"The dragon seemed pretty solid when I fought it outside the temple."
"Was but a shadow forged of spirit stuff by the wyrm's own will."

"You claim that the dragon manifested itself from ambient essence?"

Rynhaedr nods in response.
"Similar in form and function to a chanter's summon. How... unusual."
[Say nothing.]
"I try not to make a habit of doing the gods' work for them."
Rynhaedr shrugs within her armor.
"I trust you don't honestly believe that."
"I could say something to that, but I won't stop you from wishful thinking."
"Service ain't half the burden you make it out to be, you know."
"I hope that one day you see it as an honor, not a chore."
Rynhaedr holds your gaze.
"In its desperate thrashing, the wyrm has scattered this ruined realm. You may find your way stymied as you proceed."
"Do not fear to forge the path you seek."
"I do not."
"Oh. Okay."
"I beg to differ."
She nods, her eyes never leaving yours.

"There were, in the past. I remember a palace of gold and smoke. Gone now. A temple of shifting halls. Also gone." 

She frowns, almost wincing.
"These realms fell away, consumed by the White Void. I know not how long ago."

"Yes... and also no."

She frowns, forehead wrinkling in her attempt to find the words that will form an adequate explanation.
"More the echo of the kingdom's end. The whole of it fell in one great calamity, I think."
"The stubborn blindness of its chieftain has kept it suspended above the void for centuries or longer."
"Fresh and raw, that wound. In its agony it revisits itself."
"I wanted to ask you something else about this dragon."
"I'm curious about your homeland and people."
Loathing flickers across Rynhaedr's indistinct features.
"Ask your questions, then, if they will see the wyrm ended."
"Is it undead?"
"I killed the dragon and it revived. How do I kill it permanently?"
"Why is it called the White that Wends?"
"Where did the dragon come from?"
"What's it doing here?"
"You mentioned before that the dragon used wizardry..."
"Do you know where it came by such powers?"
"I want to talk about something else."

"From the north."

She frowns down at her hands.
"A beast of the Deadfire, set on dominating that place as a snow bear dominates its hunting grounds. "
"No creature, dragon or kith, rivaled it. Yet it was not content and turned its eyes against the gods."
"Rymrgand gifted our people with the Vytmádh that we might yield to him those objects or individuals that persisted beyond their... value to the clans."

"In its desire to dominate the Deadfire, the wyrm sought to retrieve one or more of the sacrificed relics."

Her scowl twists into a smirk.
"Even if it claimed the relics, the fool cannot return, its body long since destroyed."
"I wish I had that answer. Perhaps it would be enough to fight it in this place, to weaken its grip that it might finally fall into the void."
"Perhaps it found the relic it sought, its soul clinging to that object in place of an earthly form. If that object were found, perhaps it could be delivered to the Beast of Winter for dissolution."
"I can't risk falling on a perhaps, however. Not with the gate to hold."

"A vessel? It doesn't have a physical form..."

Her eyebrows draw together.
"Is it relevant?"
"Yes. I need to know what I'm facing."
"I suppose not."
"Then I would not hazard to fill my mouth with possibilities. Such distinctions interest me little."
"How terribly convenient."
"Yes. Even before it came to us, tales had reached us from the north. The wyrm's abilities were not limited to its fangs, claws, and breath - it commanded eldritch energies."
"I do not. It ate a wizard, perhaps?"
She nods, her eyes never leaving yours.
She inclines her head to you.
"What is the White that Wends like?"
"What was the White that Wends like four centuries ago?"
"Can you tell me more about the pale elves?"

"Much as it is now, I suspect. Change comes slowly to the Land."

Her gaze falls as she considers.
"Do the Glamfellen have any particular feelings about the wood elves?"
"How does a person explain their home, when they've only ever seen it with their own eyes? Travelers will claim it an endless expanse of white, featureless and bare."
"I would point to the jagged rises, the plunging coasts, the sheer rifts - to the blight storms and the snow bears - and ask of them, do you not see?"
"Still, few kith call the Land home. Only Glamfellen and the Enutanik. They possess the resolve - the vigor - required to endure the Beast of Winter's withering attentions."
"Rather than the Deceased Flame or the Land of Deer?"
"I doubt there are many deer to be found in the White that Wends."
"We Glamfellen simply call it the Land. Outsiders called it the White that Wends - likely because much of it is white and can be difficult to navigate - for the uninitiated."
Ydwin snorts derisively and shakes her head.
"I take it you feel differently, Ydwin?"
"Many kinds of kith have come to call the Land home in recent years, especially along the coastal ports."
"Remind me not to go there."
"It sounds incredible. Thank you."
"Does that sound like the home you left, Vatnir?"
"Strange that. Has the call of winter grown so loud, brother?"
Entries.female: "Strange that. Has the call of winter grown so loud, sister?"

Entries.default:
"Kith like yourself, no doubt."

She smiles faintly.

"It pains me little to speak of home."

She bows her head.
She frowns and shrugs, but says nothing.
The godlike peers at the spirit before him. Though his mask hides his expression, his hunched shoulders suggest fear.

"It's a cruel and deceptive place. She has that much right."

Face lowered, he addresses the ground more than either you or Rynhaedr.
"It is neither, young Winterborn. Hard and callous, perhaps, but pure in its intent."
He crosses his arms and averts his attention to the amorphous vista beyond.
"It is a hard land that produces hard people."
"It is fallacious to ascribe to it deeper spiritual - or worse, anthropomorphic - qualities."
"I know your kind well, girl, cowering behind words and symbols that the world doesn't dirty your perception of it."
"I know yours - quick to ascribe every faint breeze to the lungs of a god."
"And don't call me girl."
"You can't deny that the gods exist, Ydwin."
"Speak your mind, Vatnir."
The animancer frowns at you.
"I would think my acceptance of the gods' existence - and my personal adherence to Rymrgand - evidenced by my actions."
"I do not, however, grant them omnipotence, nor believe them solely responsible for every natural process."

"Haven't we wasted enough time picking at this spiritual scar?"

He waves a scornful hand at Rynhaedr.
"Let us get on with slaying this dragon or closing this portal or whatever it is you'd have us do."
"What is the relationship between the Glamfellen and Rymrgand?"
"That which your own experience wouldn't?"
"Most Glamfellen reside within the White that Wends, where we travel in clans. Life in the Land can be harsh, but it provides."
"The clan raises the young communally, each member passing on their expertise, that every child has the skills demanded by the Land."
"You sound like you miss it."
"Not their parents?"
"Each clan is as much family as nation."
"The mother helps raise the child, of course, but paternity can sometimes be... difficult to determine. Each child is a child of the clan first and foremost."
"I love the Land, and I love my people. But that life ended long ago."
"As all things do."

"You'd find the Land much transformed, gandhur. Settlements exist across the coast, trading as much in culture as goods."

Her carmine eyes drop to the frozen ground.
"In the north, maybe. Many inland clans still keep the old ways."

"And few children have the support of two parents, much less a whole clan of them."

Hard bitterness tinges the animancer's words.

"Do you ask if we like you?"

The spirit chuckles quietly.
"You're of the people. Do you?"
"I have little experience with the Sceltrfolc of Eir Glanfath. They do not welcome us among their lands."
"Aloth's okay, I guess."
"They're like anyone else, some good, some bad."
"They're soft and mewling, yet woefully unaware of these deficiencies."
"We do some trading with the Aedyrans."
The guardian nods slowly.
"I suppose I don't."
"I was hoping for the historical perspective."
"Thank you?"
"We have long venerated Rymrgand as the eldest, strongest, and wisest of the gods. He claimed the Land as his kingdom, and we as his people."
"My eldest taught that we fell from the Beast of Winter's fur as it marched across the Land, the first Glamfellen equal parts salt, snow, and divine spirit."
"What does 'veneration of Rymrgand' entail?"
"Did your elder tell you where Rymrgand came from?"
"What of the other gods?"
"Let me ask you about something else."
She nods, her eyes never leaving yours.

"Prayer, song, dance, sacrifice. The use of blessed relics. The defense of sacred sites."

With a smile, she gestures back towards the swirling pearlescent plane of the Vytmádh.
"Our priests augur his will in the entrails of the slain. They guide our travels across the Land, and we embrace the inevitable difficulties that ensue."
"Like all endings, he was inevitable from the beginning. The Babe of Spring demanded a Beast of Winter."
"My mother told me once that she believed them one in the same. That - like you, like me - Rymrgand was born to die."
"Unlike us, however, his birth gave birth to birthing, and his death will end death. He lit the flame, and he shall bury the ashes."
"They each sing their song. The flame keeps us warm. The sea provides fish, the land flesh. "
"Each provides temporary comfort against the cold, and we thank them for their gifts."
"But only Rymrgand awaits us in the White Void."
"I thought it odd, Watcher, that you possessed a sudden and thorough understanding of Ordhjóma."
"But she's speaking Ordhjóma... She's speaking Ordhjóma, isn't she?"
"Sounds like Rauataian to me, captain. Are we talking to the same ghost?"
"Are the two of you not speaking Aedyran, captain? Curious."
"How does she- It has been so long since I have heard Seki on a tongue not my own, I-"
Rynhaeder looks towards you with faintly burning eyes.
"Yes. I'm as ready as I'll ever be."
[Leave] "No. I need to further prepare."
"May the gods favor you. Give the beast a few new holes for me."
"This place decomposes spirits. Do not be surprised if the souls require repair before rendering you aid."
"It is the eldest of the realms accessible from here... and the most thoroughly decayed."
"You have girded yourself thoroughly in the determined souls of this place. You intend to go below."
"Will you help me below?"
"I swore an oath. I must guard the way."
"An oath all the more crucial if you fail."
"I see some spirit stuff clings to you. You intend to make your way below, then?"
"You intend to go then? As you are? Without whatever protection the souls in this place can provide?"
The guardian nods and peers down into the hole.
[Jump] "I am."
"Once you descend, you will be much closer to the Void's heart. There's no returning from that place. Are you certain of your course?"
[Jump] "Certain enough."
[Jump] "Not even a little."
The spirit frowns, a slight tic twisting the right corner of her mouth. Her nostrils flare.
"As if it's a chanter who can chant up itself?"

"You stride forth from the inferno unsinged."

Rynhaedr's cold curiosity feels somehow comforting as it lingers on you.

"Though an ember clings to your cloak."

Her eyes narrow.

"And have armed yourself with flint and steel. It should serve well against a corpse."

Her head cants slightly as she takes in Waidwen.
"The fire gutters. Soon it shall go out. You've ended it then, the soul within?"
"Waidwen's only here because of the Godhammer. I aim to free him."
"I have a rampaging god in need of a reminder of his past."
"Unfortunately for Rymrgand, this soul is spoken for."

"The Beast of Winter will not appreciate you removing spirits from his dominion."

She turns from you, then hesitates, glancing back over her shoulder.
"Pray he chooses not to take notice."
"He's an experienced warrior. I'd be foolish not to enlist him."
"Waidwen caused a lot of suffering. This will help him set things right."
"If he's good enough for Eothas, he's good enough for me."
"Be wary of overconfidence. The wyrm has bested many before you, and its power has only waxed with time."
"His time had come."
"Waidwen's holy war resulted in thousands of deaths and chaos across the Eastern Reach. He got what he deserved."
"With Eothas on the loose, I couldn't risk Waidwen's return to the Wheel."

"I understand. This tale is not without its logic. And we all play a part within the telling."

She bows her head to you.

Through the gaping hole Neriscrylas left in her wake you can make out chunks of desolate, slowly dissolving islands - decaying echoes of dead souls - floating between you and the endless, swirling expanse of the White Void.
[Descend to Neriscrylas' lair.]
[Walk away.]

"You have resurfaced."

Rynhaedr's cold attention roams you.

"You return from your interrogation."

Rynhaedr's gaze pierces you.
"You bear the ancient king like a babe in arms, mewling and pathetic."

"And with a crown, no less. Impressive."

She smirks at the king.
"Even now the water drains away into the Void. You've ended its king, then?"
"He deserves the same chance at rebirth granted all souls."
"His strength adds to my own, and I'll reward him with the Wheel."
"Who wouldn't want to be friends with a king?"
"You flaunt eternal laws and endanger yourself in the process. I advise greater caution going forward."
"Let's hope his strength matches his opinion of it."
"He doomed his people. Now he's going to make up for it."
"Doubtlessly the aid of a king will be invaluable in bringing the dragon low."

"I pray it so. The wyrm has persisted for far too long."

She bows her head.
"His time had come."
"Hopefully Rymrgand appreciates it."
"He was a blathering idiot. I silenced him."

"Your actions were admirable."

A small frown catches at the corners of her mouth.
"And with another soul added to your collection."

"Then she will aid you against the wyrm?"

Her attention lingers on Naxiva.
"You broke the chains and consigned the soul that forged them to oblivion."
"That place tortured her. Or she tortured herself. Either way, it's time it ended."
"I will return her to the Wheel."
"I didn't save her just to sacrifice her to a dragon!"

"You risk her. Likewise, you risk yourself. Without her assistance, you may never escape the depths."

She sighs.
"I have every confidence in her will and her strength."
"This is her sentence. Her penance. Her redemption."
"She owes me."
"I've little doubt. But is that enough to finally end the monstrosity below?"
"Her time had come."
"She'd suffered for millennia. I gave her the mercy of dissolution."
"Naxiva was a monster. I ended her."
"The White Void's master will appreciate the sacrifice. I hope, though, that it does not leave you ill-prepared for the contest with the wyrm."
You espy the dragon on a broad slab of ice directly below you. You can descend, but you see no easy method of return.
"We ain't never been great with boundaries, friend."
"Yet your choice is made. There's no unchurning the butter."
"Still, might he have served a greater purpose before his final end? No matter. Ice cannot be unshattered."

"You've returned from the White Void. That is not the usual way of things."

One corner of her mouth rises. It's almost a smile.
"What transpired? I saw the Vytmádh healed. What of the beast? Is it finally, truly slain?"
"Does it matter?"
"Neriscyrlas is no more."
"Neriscyrlas is no more."
"I carry her with me."
"I've no intention of telling you."
"Of course it- Is that not why you came here?"
"You must tell me what transpired." She begins to reach out to you, but then lets her hand drop. Still, her hungry eyes search yours.

"You're lying."

She frowns, though the expression quickly deepens into a scowl.
"I sense the wyrm's taint upon you. You carry it like a sickness."

"You jest. No... No, you don't."

Her brow twists into a scowl.
"We've nothing left to discuss."
"Do not speak to me."
"You should leave this place while the option remains to you."
"I regret what aid I granted you."

"Were you wise, you would consign that object to Rymrgand. To the Void. But wisdom is clearly not among your strengths."

She glares at you from above crossed arms.
"Well at least I'm still alive."
"He couldn't destroy it. At least I'm removing it from the Void."
"Neriscyrlas was wronged by the gods. If I can help her, I will."
"I'm not going to justify myself to you."
She straightens, squaring her stance.

"May you never die, Watcher, that you see all you cherish ground into dust."

With a shake of her head, Rymrgand's chosen guardian turns from you.

"For now perhaps. What's to keep it from returning?"

She waves you away with one hand.

"Go then. Take her from this place. See to it that you never return."

With a shake of her head, Rymrgand's chosen guardian turns from you.

"She brought her fate upon herself."

She waves you away with one hand.
"I do not see why not. Have I not aided you? Do I not deserve an answer?"
"Apparently not."
"And risk you succumbing to the Void's pull? I think not."

"I see. Do as you will, then. As if you would do any other."

With a shake of her head, Rymrgand's chosen guardian turns from you.
Rynhaedr frowns down at the frozen ground.
Rynhaedr draws in a deep and entirely unnecessary breath, then exhales. Her shoulders sag slightly, and, for the first time since you met her, the spirit seems truly relaxed.

"I've waited a very long time to hear that, Watcher."

She smiles, and you realize you can make out the outlines of objects through her body. She's fading.
"I feel my ending upon me. I've you to thank for that."
"May your journeys be safe. Or failing that, may your end be swift and merciful."
With that parting benediction, Rymrgand's chosen guardian relents to the pull of the White Void.
"I'd like to ask you about our shared homeland."

In the silence that follows the dragon's descent, a faint twinge plays along the hair on your arms. After a moment, you realize that the sensation stems from your soul - a faint echo of essence across your Watcher senses.
The fractured pieces of the armored spirit you saw rush to battle Neriscyrlas reach out to you, beckoning.
